image.altText: A male academic in glasses standing outside with his arms crossed.

props.synopsis: Almost 90 per cent of Yes voters think First Nations Australians should have a say in matters affecting them. This did not surprise researchers — until they learned 76 per cent of No voters agreed.

title.children: The three findings that surprised this ANU researcher in a 'major' survey to unpack referendum votes

image.altText: A young woman wearing a cap, black vest and work shirt. In the distance is a green hill that reads 'Piss off Ausnet'.

props.synopsis: As Australia plans to spruik its 2030 emissions reductions target progress at the UN COP28 climate conference in Dubai, an energy expert warns our climate goals are at risk unless there is a greater push to get local communities on board.

title.children: Joee is on the front line of a 'farm gate fight' that could hurt Australia's ambitious clean energy targets

image.altText: A graphic of Tiny Pinder pictured against a dark background with a basketball and a newspaper clipping

props.synopsis: In the early 1990s, the Perth Wildcats were the sporting kings of the city. But that rockstar status may have helped a brutal sexual predator hide in plain sight. WARNING: This story contains details of child sexual abuse.

title.children: The Perth Wildcats' star basketball player who was also a brutal sex offender hiding in plain sight

image.altText: Close up of Bruce Lehrmann.

props.synopsis: The former Liberal staffer is facing a fourth day on the stand as part of his defamation trial against Network Ten and journalist Lisa Wilkinson.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann denies evading chief of staff's questions about night of Brittany Higgins's alleged rape

image.altText: Birds fly out the front of Parliament House

props.synopsis: The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters recommends increasing the number of Senate seats for the ACT and the Northern Territory from two to four each, to address population changes and underscore the need for territory representation.

title.children: Federal parliamentary committee recommends doubling number of senators for ACT and Northern Territory

image.altText: Clare O'Neil looks down as she walks from the despatch box in the House of Representative

props.synopsis: The federal government is refusing to say why it opted against imposing ankle monitoring bracelets on three of the people released into the community following a landmark High Court ruling.

title.children: Detainees released from immigration detention without ankle monitoring devices

image.altText: A woman and a man hugging, crying.

props.synopsis: Plastic chairs as beds. Meals of bread and rice. Hours spent waiting for the bathroom. As former hostages return to Israel after seven weeks of Hamas captivity, information about the conditions of their confinement is emerging.

title.children: Irregular meals, benches as beds. As freed hostages return to Israel, details of their captivity emerge

image.altText: Three children holding hands walk along a street at night, with one armed miiltant in a balaclava on either side of them

props.synopsis: The latest group of freed Hamas hostages is said to include three French people, two Germans and six Argentinians. Follow live.

title.children: Hamas releases 11 hostages, Israel frees 33 Palestinians, as Gaza ceasefire is extended

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Israel releases 33 more Palestinians from its prisons
Australia taking part in multi-nation task force to crack down on Hamas funding
More than 600 high-profile Australians publish an open letter against anti-Semitism

image.altText: Emergency workers surveying damage to a house.

props.synopsis: Workers at an Adelaide business were shaken after a concrete slab from a building site fell next to a nearby home during severe thunderstorms that hit the state earlier this morning.

title.children: Thousands without power, homes damaged as thunderstorms hit SA

image.altText: A Bateau bay sign

props.synopsis: The woman in her 90s had been residing in a Bateau Bay aged care home where police allege she was attacked by a 34-year-old man.

title.children: Elderly woman dies almost two weeks after alleged nursing home sex assault

image.altText: The stump of a felled tree at Lane Cove with a person in khaki visible in the background

props.synopsis: Another mass killing of trees and plants has taken place in Longueville on Sydney's lower north shore, just months after more than 200 were cut down in a nearby suburb.

title.children: Mass tree killing on Sydney Harbour is 'worst act of environmental vandalism' locals have seen

image.altText: Mark Butler sitting back in a motorised wheelchair, looking pensive.

props.synopsis: New South Wales is the last of the states to make voluntary assisted dying legal, but the first to give free choice on administering drugs and a shorter wait time.

title.children: From today voluntary assisted dying will be allowed in NSW. Mark wants to be one of the first to access it

image.altText: Doctor prepares saline drip

props.synopsis: An urgent patient safety alert has been issued to hospitals and clinics, ordering them to stop using two saline products believed to be linked to the outbreak of a dangerous bacteria.

title.children: Death at Queensland hospital suspected to be linked to contaminated saline

image.altText: An aerial view of an upside-down four-wheel-drive vehicle on a beach, with emergency services workers clustered around it.

props.synopsis: The 4WD instructor's warnings come after a rollover on Teewah Beach near Noosa killed the 24-year-old driver and injured four passengers on Sunday.

title.children: Ignoring these off-road driving tips could get you killed, instructor warns

image.altText: Dodson, with a long grey beard and wide brimmed hat marked with the colours of the Aboriginal flag.

props.synopsis: Labor senator Pat Dodson, known as the "father of reconciliation" after decades of advocacy for Indigenous people, will retire from federal politics on January 26.

title.children: Pat Dodson, known as the 'father of reconciliation', to retire from Senate on Australia Day

image.altText: Cheng Lei appears on Q+A.

props.synopsis: In the final episode Q+A of 2023, formerly incarcerated journalist Cheng Lei issues a warning about China, and Kalarie man Todd Fernando discusses why the Indigenous Voice to Parliament failed at the referendum.

title.children: 'Don't want naive people going there': Cheng Lei's China warning to Australians

image.altText: Portrait of Michael Barnett. He wears glasses and wears a floral shirt.

props.synopsis: Michael was once open to having children, but that openness was shut down, time and time again.

title.children: People assume it was my choice not to have children. It wasn't

image.altText: A shopping trolley full of essentials items like fruit, water, and eggs

props.synopsis: Aussies love an abbreviation, especially when it's a fun way of referring to a serious topic. It's a trend that seen the term "cozzie livs" named Word of the Year.

title.children: Light-hearted term for cost of living named Macquarie Dictionary's Word of 2023

image.altText: Dozens of people of all ages line up outside a "For Lease" sign at a Sydney apartment building.

props.synopsis: It is now cheaper to buy an apartment than to lease one in many capital cities, according to new analysis that further highlights the ongoing rental affordability crunch for lower-income households.

title.children: 'A depressing set of data': Renters would now be financially better off buying one-third of places they rent

image.altText: A soldier sitting on the edge of a tank

props.synopsis: While the pause in hostilities has provided some heartwarming moments, the death and destruction in Gaza could continue for months, write Riley Stuart and Orly Halpern.

title.children: If this was supposed to be an Israel-Hamas ceasefire, strap yourself in

image.altText: Palestinian woman cooks in front of her family's  building destroyed in the Israeli bombardment of Gaza

props.synopsis: Mediator Qatar says a deal has been reached to extend a truce between Israeli and Hamas forces in Gaza by two days, continuing a pause in seven weeks of warfare that has killed thousands and laid waste to the Palestinian enclave.

title.children: Deal reached to extend Gaza truce by two days

image.altText: A woman walks to work

props.synopsis: The national gender pay gap has fallen to 21.7 per cent. In February, a big shift in how it is reported — naming companies individually — will shake up employment and likely narrow the gap further.

title.children: The national gender pay gap has fallen to a new low, and a decision to name and shame could push it lower

image.altText: Actress Rachel Zegler gives a sarcastic bow as Lucy Gray in the Hunger Games prequel.

props.synopsis: Uli grew up in post-war Germany, so the possibility of a Hunger Games like dystopia feels like "a very real thing". This is how the film's production designer tackled the prequel.

title.children: Nazi Germany's influence on the new Hunger Games film

image.altText: Close-up of Australia's five, 10, 20, 50 and 100 dollar bills.

props.synopsis: The Australian dollar has risen to its highest level in nearly four months on increased bets the US Federal Reserve is finished with its interest rate hikes. Follow live.

title.children: ASX opens higher, Australian dollar rises to almost four-month high

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Aussie dollar nearly at a four-month high, gold shines above $US2,000
Australian shares to open flat, ahead of retail data and RBA governor's comments

image.altText: Composite image of Alan Joyce and Kelly Bayer Rosmarin.

props.synopsis: Despite the dire consequences, many of our corporate leaders have yet to grasp the lessons of history and how repeated denials, offloading of responsibility and obfuscation end up coming back to bite, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Pent-up frustration unfolds on corporate Australia

image.altText: Abdullah El-Nasher is led into court by a custody worker.

props.synopsis: A man who fatally shot one man and injured another outside a boxing event in Melbourne's inner north-west in 2019 is sentenced to 29 years and three months behind bars.

title.children: Melbourne shooter jailed for nearly three decades over boxing event murder

image.altText: A young woman wearing a black headscarf and black eyeliner looks serious.

props.synopsis: Australians of faith who want to eat less meat can sometimes find themselves torn between their religious identity and environmentalism.

title.children: 'God will never be happy with you': How Lujayn overcame the clash between veganism and her religion

image.altText: picture of a man surrounded by smoke after using vape

props.synopsis: Single-use vapes will be banned from being imported into Australia from January in the first stage of a government crackdown against recreational vaping.

title.children: Federal government rolls out timeline for major vaping crackdown

props.synopsis: The manager of a charity that organises food donations for people in need says she is "distressed" by the amount of produce a new Townsville supermarket has sent to landfill.

title.children: Food charity 'distressed' by dumped fruit, vegetables after Aldi launches new supermarket

image.altText: a black-and-white close-up of a woman's hand passing a set of car keys to a man

props.synopsis: New research has highlighted the ways perpetrators of violence and coercive control use vehicles — and the paperwork associated with them, like insurance policies — against their partners.

title.children: 'That's a deliberate strategy': How perpetrators of domestic violence can manipulate car insurance to control partners

image.altText: A portrait photo of Malakai with his yidaki standing in the park

props.synopsis: Gunaikurnai teenager Malakai’s asthma symptoms improved after learning the didjeridu, with experts agreeing breathing exercises can improve quality of life for asthmatics.

title.children: Malakai used to feel breathless. He thinks learning the yidaki helped change that
